tier.item: 7 Languages like Turkish that have a similar syntax, but with case marking, not clitics,
can be treated in a similar way, essentially with the case markers occupying the head of
the "clitic" phrase, and licensing the L-phrase in accusative contexts.
8 It should be noted that Chung (1998) denies her previous claim, and proposes instead
that the grammar of Chamorro is insensitive to the specificity/definiteness of direct
objects. If the claim in Chung (1998) is most accurate, it could be that indefinite direct
objects are in a state of change toward a system more like the Palauan system, where
indefinites lack any kind of Case marking--in the situation of Chamorro it would mean
that lack of a definite article is also coming to mean lack of (Structural) Case.
7 Languages like Turkish that have a similar syntax, but with case marking, not clitics,
can be treated in a similar way, essentially with the case markers occupying the head of
the "clitic" phrase, and licensing the L-phrase in accusative contexts.
